TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (No. 4) Bill and the Income Tax ( International Agreements) Amendment Bill, which are before the Senate, are complex and important Bills in the Government's taxation measures arising from the Budget and other decisions that have been taken. They cover a wide area of taxation law and in themselves bring many changes to the taxation law. There are differing reasons for the Bills. For instance, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill is one that has been introduced to make substantial amendments to many of the offence and prosecution provisions. The amendments have arisen partly from a review which was initiated during the term of the former Government when the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, recognised that in many instances throughout the taxation Acts, rates had not been increased for many years. There has been no updating, upgrading or review of provisions relating to penalty and prosecution. So in that context we welcome the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill and the many changes that it seeks to make.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer to some matters which are of concern to us a little later. I now refer to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (No. 4) Bill which again has many provisions within it and seeks to change many matters, most of them arising out of Budget announcements that have been made by the Government. One of the matters that I wish to refer to relates to transfer of losses within a company group. In this context, it is interesting to note that the Government has reversed its decision of March 1983 and will now proceed with the proposal on this matter that had been introduced by the former Government. It is a proposal that would enable a loss suffered by one resident company to be an allowable deduction to another resident company in the same company group. That seemed to us to be a suitable and responsible proposal for change, and we welcome its introduction in the legislation that is before us. In introducing this proposal no mention was made of the fact that it was a reversal of the Government's previous decision but it is nevertheless an important initiative and we welcome it, whatever description it is given.

The business sector should be reminded, and I am sure it already knows, that the new proposal applies only to losses incurred in the 1984-85 year or later, effectively denying the business sector deductions on the 1982-83 and 1983-84 losses which could have been covered if the previous Government's decision had been upheld on the change of government. The delay related to difficulties perceived by the business sector is caused by the requirement that there be 100 per cent common ownership between companies. This has seriously disadvantaged those groups which have been unable by very small percentages to complete mergers and takeovers. The present legislation before us makes no concession in this direction. When we reach the Committee stage in dealing with this legislation the Opposition will move an amendment that relates to this matter.

Other provisions within the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (No. 4) Bill relate to such things as capital expenditure on non-residential income-producing buildings. The provision within the legislation increases the annual deduction allowable to 4 per cent of the cost of construction. This provision will cost something like $4m in the 1985-86 year. Although this is a modest extension of the capital expenditure depreciation provision it is something that will be of assistance to the construction industry and to those who gain their income from tourism. I think it is probably an overstatement to say that it is a significant boost. It is helpful and I am sure it will be welcomed but it is still a fairly modest increase that has been given.

We welcome also the extension of the investment allowance cut-off date for installation of new equipment from July 1986 to July 1987. This will cost up to $100m and it will be helpful. I think the Government again needed to look at its attitude with regard to investment allowance and the assistance and the incentive that it gave. I am glad that the extension of time provided for in this legislation has been given. In this legislation in the area of mineral exploration and prospecting, deductibility of expenditure is extended beyond a taxpayer's mining and associated income to income from any source. That proposal is something that has been suggested to me through the years as being desirable, and I am glad to see its introduction. This provision will cost about $8m in the 1985-86 year. It is again of modest benefit to the mining industry, but it is of benefit and is something that people felt would be an incentive to investment in mineral exploration. If a provision of this kind can give such an incentive just how much additional expenditure will be given in this area and what beneficial effect it will have remain to be seen. I recognise that the very substantial representations that have been made over the years have always been along the lines that that was all that was needed to increase rapidly the investment that people were prepared to make. So it will be interesting to see just what does occur as a result of this provision.

The increases in zone rebates are matters that were referred to in the Budget. They will cost something like $11m in a full year. They increase the basic component in zones A and B. This move is a recognition of the disadvantage experienced by people living in those zones in comparison with people in the rest of Australia. This is the Bill that also provides for the extension of the dependent spouse rebate to de facto spouses. On this matter, I wish on behalf of the Opposition to make a statement similar to that which was made by my colleague John Howard in the House of Representatives when the legislation was before that House. I want to make a quite clear statement that the Opposition is unhappy about this extension of the spouse rebate in the way in which it is provided for in the legislation. It is not our intention to try to defeat the relevant clause or to move an amendment to it but I use this opportunity to state that extension of the spouse rebate is not and was not our policy throughout all the years of government and it is a change that we resisted when we were in government. I recognise that representations have been made. They were made to me. The contrast between social security legislation and income tax legislation has often quite erroneously been used as a reason for making a change in the income tax law, but after all the considerations that were given to this matter when in government, we did not feel that it was a change that we were prepared to make in income tax law.

The former Treasurer reminded the House on Tuesday that he had had many representations but he resisted them, and he expressed the view of the former Government that governments should continue to discriminate in favour of orthodox marital arrangements and that in doing so governments were not passing moral judgments or moral sanctions on people's arrangements. In making the comments that I make on behalf of the Opposition, I am not making such judgments in this instance. It is not our intention to use this opportunity to have any debate on matters of social change but simply to state that as far as income tax law is concerned it would not be our policy to extend the spouse rebate to those who are in de facto arrangements. I will follow again what was said on Tuesday by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in debate on these Bills. He said:

There are occasions when governments ought to pay some regard to symbolism, and I think it is very unfortunate that the Government of this country has decided to remove yet another bias in our system towards orthodox marriage arrangements.

It has to be said, as the Deputy Leader said, that we are not making moral judgments about people's personal arrangements; rather we are looking at those instances where governments are required to make laws. They are required to extend benefits. By their preferences they are giving recognition either to a situation that might have arisen in the case of, say, social security legislation, where we are looking at income support or, in the case of tax law, a benefit being widened to include another group in the community. I make those comments on behalf of the Opposition as an expression of our view that it is not our policy that this should have been done, but it is not something on which we will be moving any amendment at this stage.

The other matters in the tax Bills before us relate to such a diversity of things that many of them can be referred to as we work through them in the Committee stage. The Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill is one on which there has been very little comment. I make very little comment on it because the changes it makes are in accordance with agreements with other countries, in this case Belgium and Malta. The Opposition has no opposition to those measures.

The Income Tax Assessment Amendment (No. 4) Bill covers such things as the dependent spouse rebate and the rebate for pensioners and social security beneficiaries and makes Budget provisions for them. The changes that have been made to income tax law, in at least the rebate for pensioners instance, endeavour to offset the disadvantage that has resulted from the failure to index the tax threshold. The measure before us lifts the taxable income level below which the $250 pensioner rebate is available to a figure of $5,533 and to $5,595 for subsequent years, This is an endeavour to overcome the disadvantage that would be suffered by pensioners as incomes rise and they are affected by tax thresholds. My colleague, Senator Messner, made some comments on this not so very long ago and showed that it really does not have the same effect as another way of dealing with these matters could have had. However, it is the Budget proposal.

I want to make a brief comment with regard to the provisional tax that is to be calculated and the basis on which it is to be calculated under this legislation. The legislation provides for the 1984-85 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of a 10 per cent rise on 1983-84 taxable income and varies the tax rates as outlined in the Budget along with the Medicare levy. It is of some interest to us that as the major component for this year's provisional tax rise is farm incomes which are forecast to fall this year, it would seem that the Budget's 10 per cent assumption about provisional tax payers' incomes could be a rather heroic sort of assumption. I think it is not disputed that farm incomes will be likely to fall substantially in this year. It is of interest to us that this figure of 10 per cent for the calculation is the one on which the Budget relies. Nobody would expect that figure to be achieved in terms of the provisional income tax for those people concerned.

Other things could be said again and again in a general tax debate, because it is a public debate in this country at present. Some people are awaiting tax policies from the Opposition which will be released in the very near future. Others are waiting for the outcome of the review of its tax policy that the Government has stated is occurring. As we have said in other debates, we cannot look at income tax without looking at Medicare as being an identified levy but in no sense different from the levy of income tax. When we consider the additional expenditure requirement of Medicare of something like $2 billion and we know that the levy is to raise something like $1.2 billion, we need to consider the fact that there is an increase in personal tax, whether identified or not, to cover that additional expenditure.

When considering the figures for the tax itself and the Medicare levy, it is of some interest to me at least to consider this month's financial statement of transactions released by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). The Minister's statement released just a few days ago demonstrates the effect of the Government 's policies on tax because it shows such figures as a 20 per cent rise in gross pay as you earn tax over the first two months of 1984-85. It also shows a 31 per cent decrease in PAYE refunds and a 33 per cent growth in net tax PAYE receipts. The figures that relate to refunds are of interest because they reflect the removal of health care and housing rebates and other tax changes which means that hundreds of thousands of people who would have received tax refunds have not received them. In fact, I am sure that both Government and Opposition members and senators would have received representations from constituents who in this year not only did not receive the tax refund that they expected but who also received assessments for additional tax to be paid. That is of significance when governments or oppositions talk about tax policy. People who had expectations of certain levels of tax now find that their expectations have not been realised; in fact, they have the difficulty of meeting some of their commitments under tax assessments.

I am sure that public interest in the Government's tax policy is one that is growing and one which will grow as people see the reflection of these figures in the changes in refunds and the growth in net PAYE receipts in the most recent statement that has been released by the Minister for Finance. Government tax policy is of interest because from public statements made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other Ministers we know that the Economic Planning Advisory Council is the body that is working closely with the Government on tax policy. If we accept that the Budget itself was a result of the strong influence of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and we now hear that the tax policy to be put to the Government is the responsibility of EPAC, we await with some interest, in view of some of the statements of members of EPAC, a tax policy statement. I believe we can assume that the tax policy that will emerge from EPAC will introduce new taxes. It will introduce such things as a capital gains tax. I hope that the tax policy will be available for public reception before we go into the forthcoming election because the tax changes to rebates and other areas made by the present Government-such as the fact that there has not been recognition of growth in wages and the five new tax structures provided in the Budget-make many people wonder what exactly will be their personal tax commitment by the end of this financial year.

I hope that any tax policy changes arising from EPAC or from the Government will be made clear and that people will not be left in a position in which under the present tax policy they are required to make increased tax payments. The Government talked about giving people a $7.60 a week tax refund, but ignored the fact that there was something like a 23 per cent increase in tax. We await with some interest the decisions on a general tax policy that will be placed before us. I hope those decisions will not be put to one side until after the next election which is almost upon us.

With regard to one of the Bills, I said earlier that I was principally concerned about the introduction of a reverse onus of proof. I will deal with the matter in more detail when we move into the Committee stage. In the debate in the House of Representatives on this matter the shadow Treasurer expressed our concern. He sought information and response from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford). I read with some interest and very carefully the brief response that was given by the Minister. It did not entirely cover our concerns; nor did it answer the representations we have had from lawyers and others on this very important matter. When we first expressed our concern about it, it was not in response to the lawyers, the professional body. Our concern was at the reverse onus of proof. I know that it will be said that it exists in other legislation. It was certainly introduced in the Companies Act when we were in government and, as was mentioned by the Minister in the House of Representatives, it is in other legislation. But it is something that needs to be treated seriously and carefully before it is introduced. For instance, I note that the Digest of Bills and bodies that study these matters have drawn attention to this.

Whilst we make it clear that we regard these Bills as Budget Bills and we do not seek in any way to hold up the many changes that arise from the Budget with which we concur, we believe that a second look at the introduction of the reverse onus of proof in this legislation is something that would be worthy of consideration. I foreshadow that following the Committee stage I will seek to have the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1984 analysed by a Senate committee so that those in the community who have concerns about it will have the opportunity to put their points of view. In addition, the Government would have more time in which to consider those matters. That will be our intention in the Committee stage.

I have another concern which might be considered small in terms of money with regard to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (No. 4) Bill 1984. It relates to gifts of fodder and stock that were made following the disastrous Ash Wednesday fires. We accept that we were the Government at the time facing the electors. We made a public commitment that gifts of fodder and stock would be allowable tax deductions. We accept that we made that commitment. We believe that this was a very helpful undertaking in that people who had something that could be shared at that time were encouraged to give some relief. We understand that a public commitment was also made by the then Leader of the Opposition, now Prime Minister, that a Labor government would also make gifts of fodder and stock an allowable taxation deduction. We would have thought that the Government could have used this opportunity to fulfil that commitment and to make the legislation applicable to that year. Therefore, again at the Committee stage, we will move an amendment, which we hope will be supported, which will have the effect of making gifts of fodder and stock that were made following the disastrous fires to be allowable deductions. Again, we will await the outcome of the Committee's response and hope that there will be support for it in this place.

Some other matters may be raised by members of the Opposition. I see that there is a quite lengthy speakers list on the Bills. I will be raising matters on behalf of the Opposition during and following the Committee stage. With those remarks, I hope that the Bills are given a speedy passage because of the requirements of the Government to have this taxation legislation passed before the Parliament rises. I recognise that amended legislation might need to go to the other place. I understand, too, that government amendments will be moved in this place and that will require action in the other place later. With those comments, I commend the Bills for the reasons that I have outlined. I have foreshadowed our opposition to just a few measures that I hope the Senate might support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — I would like to reinforce what Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has just said about the back-down by the Government with respect to tax exemption on gifts that were made to relieve the burden faced by the victims of the disastrous Ash Wednesday fire stricken areas. I can recall that day very well because after flying through an incredibly turbulent sky on that day Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and I were greeted with the news when we landed of the disasters that had occurred in South Australia and Victoria in particular. I would like to make the point at this stage that the Government is negligent in not providing sales tax exemption for fire equipment installed by householders in those fire prone areas who wish to prevent similar disasters to that which occurred on that unhappy day.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the whole question of tax restructuring has been neglected for a number of years. I do not excuse previous governments for that either because, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and I emphasised last year when speaking in the Budget debate, it is quite clear that Australia on a comparable basis is one of the most highly directly taxed nations and one of the lowest indirectly taxed countries. There is a need to restructure our taxation system to relieve the personal taxation burden in some way or other and to use the indirect area of taxation. It has been suggested on many occasions that consideration should be given to imposing, say, flat tax to a certain level of income. I suggest that consideration ought to be given to re-examining this. It is suggested that the tax free level ought to be increased. The tax free level of income at the moment is something of the order of $4,595 a year. The Australian Labor Party, of course, promised that the tax free level would be raised to $5,000 a year. This promise has not been forthcoming yet. We have become used to the Labor Party not honouring a promise it made during the last election campaign. But these things need to be looked at. We ought to look at the rate of taxation on overtime, in the interests of encouraging people to work harder, increase their productivity and become more efficient and effective.

We should look at other areas of taxation. I believe that it would be viable to introduce a flat rate of tax to a certain level of income. Senator Messner, with his accounting background, may be able to put arguments for or against this matter. However, it is worthy of examination. Perhaps we could tax incomes of up to $30,000 a year at 25 per cent or 27 1/2 per cent and incomes above $30,000 at no more than, say, 40 per cent. But I think those sorts of propositions ought to be examined. I think that that sort of measure would help to prevent tax evasion . It would certainly minimise the problem in that area. An examination must also be made of the cash economy. I have been given an estimate that something of the order of $10,000m a year could be involved. I think that Senator Messner said that the amount is something like 10 per cent of gross revenue. He would have a pretty good idea about that.

The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), made a point two days ago about what the Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, said at a meeting of the Australia-America Association in New York earlier in the year. Mr Keating said that the next thing on the agenda was to reform the taxation system and our taxation structure. I am sure we welcome that thought. It is a question of how the Labor Party intends to implement it. Mr Howard also drew attention to the possibility of the Government introducing a capital gains tax and probably a wealth tax if it is re-elected. He challenged the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to say where he stood on those two issues. He also made mention of the possibility of a reintroduction of death duties. The Government must make its intentions perfectly clear on those three matters.

Many comments have been made throughout the community with respect to death duties, and capital gains taxes. I refer in the first instance to a statement by the Prime Minister in May this year when he denied that the Government was considering introducing a death duty as a possible alternative to its controversial assets test scheme. He has not made many comments about that in recent times. He said at that time that a death duty proposal was being considered by the Government's Panel of Review of Proposed Income and Assets Test but that that did not mean that the Government had it under consideration. At that time, however, Mr Hawke, conceded that the imposition of such a tax would seriously affect children and the upward mobility of families. In an article in the Australian of 9 May 1984 he is reported to have said:
. . . the proposal was one of several being considered by the panel, which is due to report back to the Government late this month or early next.

The Government should inform the Senate and the community of its intention because it is quite clear that death duties will affect the children of people who have died and it will clearly affect the upward mobility of families. I have always said that a capital gains tax would have a detrimental effect not only on the wealthy people of this country, who make up a fairly small percentage of the population, but also on the majority of the working people of Australia, who can be regarded as being relatively affluent when compared with the working people of, say, the early 1900s. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 5 May, written by Mr Ross Gittins, the Economics Editor, drew attention to this point. In that article he referred to a paper by John R. Piggott entitled 'The Distribution of Wealth in Australia-a Survey'. It is discussion paper No. 93 from the Centre for Economic Policy Research, Australian National University, Canberra. The article stated:

The proportion of wealth held by the top 1 per cent of adult individuals has decreased sharply since 1915. The share of wealth held by the bottom 90 per cent increased from 22 per cent in 1915 to between 35 and 40 per cent in the late 60s .
The article makes the comment that it is difficult-at the moment, I think pretty impossible-to work out the distribution of income in Australia. The article stated:
The short answer is that we don't know a lot about the distribution of income in Australia and we know even less about the distribution of wealth. The figures we do have are pretty rough-and-ready.

We have been told that the share of wealth held by the bottom 90 per cent of the population increased from 22 per cent in 1915 to between 35 and 40 per cent in the late 1960s. Obviously the figures for the present would show a further increase. A capital gains tax will not affect the people the Labor Party would like it to affect most of all; it will affect the people whom the Labor Party purports to represent.

The farmers have had something to say about the issue, too. Farmers, of course, are always regarded as being plutocrats, land owners of great wealth. However, the average annual farm income at the moment would amount to only a few thousands dollars-I am not sure of the exact figure. An article in the Age on 27 June this year, headlined 'Farmers allege deals on capital gains tax', states:
Deals were being done between business and the Federal Government to ease the introduction of capital gains taxes, the National Farmers Federation claimed . . .

The president of the federation, McLachlan, told the annual conference of the Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association that farmers had to act urgently against capital gains tax before a positive image was built up for such a tax.
''If we are not careful the farm sector will find 'consensus' (on capital gains tax) which has been reached without the participation of ourselves, the major affected party.''

The federation fears that the Federal Government is engineering community support for capital gains tax. Farmers believe that the business community was roped into supporting centralised wage fixing at last year's national economic summit.
Mr McLachlan said farmers were being hurt by Australia's deteriorating international competitiveness and high exchange rates. ''Interest rates will be the key to the return of rural prosperity.''

I think that is a very true statement and one that ought to be regarded by the Government as significant. An international expert from the United Kingdom cast doubts upon a capital gains tax. I quote from a statement made by Mr Peter Browne, the head of Touche Ross International's tax services, in an article in the Age of 13 June 1984:
Returns from a capital gains tax were unlikely to be significant in the short term and might not be high enough to enable cuts in personal tax . . .

In the UK, which has had such a tax for 20 years, the yield was less than 1 per cent of total tax revenues. ''Not only that, the imposition of the tax has driven a large number of small investors out of the stock and gilt-edge market.' ' This figure did not include the costs of collecting the impost.

He criticised a capital gains tax because the Government was able to offer . . . exempt bonds, diverting funds from the private sector ''which tends to distort the operation of free capital markets.''

I believe those points ought to be observed by Australians. Quite often we make the same mistakes that have been proved to be wrong in overseas countries and fail to take corrective remedies here. In fact the opposite has been the case many times where we have followed the mistakes that have been proven to have been made in overseas countries. Australia, being a young developing country, should be in a position to capitalise not only with respect to our economic considerations but also with respect to our economic considerations but also with respect to the development and restructuring of our industries. We have seen in Australia that we can lead the world in initial research in matters such as Interscan. We have done much initial work on the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar. We are doing important work on green laser technology for oceanography. We are poised and in a position to lead the world in computer software design work which could be the basis for an incredibly large industry in Australia. Yet we have failed to capitalise on these initiatives.

One thing that particularly distresses me-as it does the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, and well he might be disturbed and distressed-is that the Government has reduced its funding of research in Australia. We have seen the hypocrisy of the Prime Minister who only a few days ago challenged industry to spend more on research and developing its initiatives. That is all very well for him to say that, on the one hand. He has not given industry any encouragement to do that. On the other hand, in the current Budget he has reduced the amount being spent on research in Australia. For every dollar spent on initial research in Australia, $10 has to be spent to develop it.

Successive governments have failed to recognise the point which I made in conjunction with my colleagues on the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment when we presented a report to the then Government in 1979. We said that industry in Australia had lost its entrepreneurial drive and that the reason was that governments were preoccupied with propping up inefficiency in industry through tariff protection and that, rather, governments should be selective in their attitude to tariffs. They should examine those industries that need to be encouraged to become more entrepreneurial and to encourage them to spend those $10: $1 compared with pure research and development and provide them with tax incentives to develop the initiatives so that we can capitalise in many areas in the international world market.

I can point to several areas. I have already mentioned Interscan. We have lost the initiative there and other countries are now capitalising on it. We can go back further with respect to zerography which was developed in the defence laboratories in South Australia. What did we do? We did not develop that to our advantage. The Japanese did. They are capitalising on the economic and employment advantages of that technology. It is very important for any government or successive governments to have regard to that. But we see the hypocrisy of this overrated Prime Minister. I believe the Press is culpable in praising up this man, this Mr 73 per cent inordinately--

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixty-six now.
—It has dropped to 66 per cent.
—It beats 25.

—It may beat 25 per cent but I do not regard that as important. I recall one occasion when Malcolm Fraser was at the lowest point with respect to the popularity polls but we beat the Australian Labor Party into the ground on that occasion, and we will beat it into the ground on the next occasion. I wish to talk about this overrated Prime Minister. Who is he? He is a small man with an inflated ego and with a very good coiffure. He has his hair done regularly so that he presents himself well and he instructs his Ministers to become--
—Point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. The honourable senator is descending into personal abuse which is quite inappropriate for a chamber as dignified as this.
—There is no point of order but, Senator Jessop, can I just suggest that you refrain from participating in that kind of debate.

—I just wanted to praise the Prime Minister by saying how elegant he looks dressed in his blue suit. One would almost think he was a Liberal by the way he parades himself in the public arena. What is more, I understand that Ministers of the Labor Government have been instructed to smarten themselves up a bit and dress a bit more elegantly than they used to do when in opposition. In this way I believe they are presenting a phoney image to the public. The polls that are being carried out in Australia are quite wrong because this Prime Minister, having broken most of his election promises--
—You don't like him, I gather.

—I am not talking about him personally. As a matter of fact I regard him personally as quite an affable fellow. I have no personal objection to him but I do say that he is overrated in the eyes of the public largely because of the media giving him inordinate and I think preferential treatment. If one looks at the record of the Government it is clear that the success with which it has met has been because it has followed the policies of the Fraser Government. The Fraser Government initiated the wage pause, and very wisely. The present Government is continuing that, with the exception of course, to which I referred last night, that it has chosen to allow certain parts of the Public Service-the top echelons of the Public Service and statutory authorities and judges-to have an 11.7 per cent wage increase. Apart from that, it has been successful in following the policies established by the Fraser Government in containing and reducing inflation. I give the Government credit for recognising the good sense established by the previous Government in that respect. Of course , the Prime Minister has capitalised in every way with the breaking of the drought. This has helped him. That is fair enough. I suppose we would welcome that sort of assistance. He has also capitalised on Australia's winning the America's Cup and all the other sporting events.

SPEECH.PARA: But the Opposition and the public believe that the things that have been introduced by this Government by way of taxation on superannuation, Medicare and the much discussed and much hacked about assets test have been absolute disasters. I have had many people come to me complaining that their tax rebate cheques have shrunken considerably over the last 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of them have to pay tax.

—I was going to make that point. Some of them, instead of having received very much smaller rebate cheques, now find themselves in the position where they have in fact to pay more tax. That is what the Labor Government does for the small wage earners, the pay as you earn taxpayers and all those people who look to this Government for some sort of support. I conclude by referring again to the question of capital gains tax. This comment comes from the Australian Financial Review of 27 June. It was a comment made by Dr Jeffry Timmons, Professor of Entrepreneurial Studies at Babson College in Massachusetts . He had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . President Johnson, looking for more money to pour into Vietnam, lifted the capital gains tax rate from 25 per cent to 48 per cent.

The inflow of new capital dropped from $171 million in 1969, when the tax rose, to $97 million the next year and continued down to a low of just $17 million in 1976. Similarly, the number of new small companies floated on the stockmarket slumped from about 900 in 1969 to none in 1971.
Since the tax rate was cut back to 28 per cent in 1978, new venture capital raised has gone from $39 million in 1977 to more than $4,000 million last year, with a now effective 20 per cent tax rate.

If we want to throttle industry and throttle the enterprise of the large majority of people in Australia, the answer is to introduce a capital gains tax and stifle incentive to invest in Australia, and stifle people who wish to provide for themselves in the future while at the same time possibly saving the Government a lot of money in the future with respect to pensions. With those few words I support what Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has had to say with respect to the Opposition's view on these measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing that needs to be said about these taxation Bills is that they are part of the Budget of this Government. The second thing that needs to be said is that this Government is the highest taxing government since World War II. We have seen personal income tax go up by some 23 per cent in this Budget, yet this follows the 1983-84 year when so many tax rebates, such as for Medicare and housing interest and also, of course, the general concessional rebate, were abolished and/or effectively put out of use in such a way as to result in an enormous impact on the individual taxpayer in Australia. As my colleague, who has just resumed his seat, has said, many people have seen the impact of this in their latest tax refunds. They have realised that their refunds this year have fallen dramatically and many people, instead of getting money back from the Australian Taxation Office, as they usually would, find that they are faced with having to pay tax.
—They are being taxed twice in a lot of areas.

—As my colleague has pointed out-I think he is referring to Medicare-people are in fact being taxed twice. These circumstances are becoming apparent to the Australian people, but they are nothing compared with what this Government has in mind for us if it succeeds in winning the election in December . We know that because none other than the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, has already told us that we have to put up taxes in order to pay more for science and technology and for developments in other areas of government expenditure. That is on the record, and we have the first signs of it here. My colleague Senator Jessop has already referred to the prospect of a capital gains tax or other kinds of capital taxes which this Government has in mind. We have on the record the authority of none other than the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) on this because in this last year he has introduced an assets test. In Labor Essays of 1983 he said: 'You cannot bring in an assets test for pensioners without introducing a capital gains tax'. Consequently we will be hearing more about that in the new year if Labor is re- elected.

SPEECH.PARA: These things have to be discussed in this kind of forum at this time because they are vital to the understanding of what this Hawke Labor Government is all about. It is about obfuscation and about putting the issues under the carpet until after December when it can come in with a brand new set of proposals having been re-elected, if the people can be misled in that way, and consequently putting them into practice later. We know already, of course, that the runs are on the board about the way in which this Government can cover its tracks. Look at the misleading statements about the lump sum superannuation tax. We were going to have a tax of 30 per cent, but when we finally get down to it, people find they are paying 31 per cent, and it is taking more out of their pockets than the Government originally proposed in the legislation. That is the way this Government behaves, manoeuvering behind the scenes, behind the curtains , to cover its tracks and to get on with doing things that obviously are not attractive in terms of vote winning power.

Let us come to some of the points in this legislation. There are some rather worthy propositions included in this legislation, and the first one is the transfer of company losses within company groups. I believe this is a major step forward. This is something which was proposed by the former Government and, was knocked off by this Government when it came to power as being one of its major steps forward in the hard decision area. Now of course it has reversed its opinion on that and reintroduced the measure in order to take account of something that the former Government, the Fraser Government, had thought through at the time. I think the Government is to be credited with some intelligence in having recognised the truth of those proposals, and we do not take that away from it.

There are one or two points that I ask the Minister to advise us upon during his winding up remarks. Firstly, on page 2 of the second reading speech of the Minister for Housing and Construction and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) I read this:
. . . a loss of one company in a group will be able to be transferred to other members of the company group in any of the seven years succeeding the year of loss.

That seems to indicate to me that we are talking about a carry-back of losses and a reopening of former assessments of other companies. I would like to know whether that in fact is so and whether the Government did intend that, because, to my mind, it does open a very important principle, and one for which I have argued over a long period. That is that as well as carrying forward losses to be offset against future incomes of companies, that principle should also apply, perhaps within certain time limits, back to past assessments so as to take advantage of that as well. I am thinking of the peculiar circumstances that sometimes arise with companies with special and exceptional sources of income such as project builders and people of that kind. Nevertheless, I would like the Minister's statements on whether my understanding of that is correct and whether that is the Government's intention.

I notice also in this area that the amount of tax forgone is claimed to be $ 200m in the 1985-86 year and that in future years this is expected to drop to about $50m. There is no indication of when this would occur, but I would like to know how the government can confidently expect that there would be a significant drop in the cost of this proposal when it has no way of assessing what would be the level of losses of individual companies, and especially of companies within groups, in the years ahead. As to the general proposition that there is likely to be a drop, I would have thought that even applying the general reasoning in connection with inflation, we could only expect that level to rise. I would like to hear some explanation of this.

On the question of the dependent spouse rebate, we have made our position quite clear. The Opposition is very concerned about the measure that the Government has brought down. This is, of course, in relation to the extension of the spouse rebate to de facto relationships. I will not go over the same ground as my colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, but I would like to make one point. I have very great concern about how the Taxation Commissioner will be able to establish what is a bona fide domestic relationship in the circumstances and what degree of intrusion will be raised by the tax office in establishing that such circumstances exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have the same objection to the Director-General of Social Security?

—I am merely asking for the Minister's explanation. I do not want to debate the matter in those terms. I would like to hear from the Minister 's advisers, through him. I understand the Minister's point, but I would like to know what the Taxation Commissioner is proposing in this respect. If the Minister can satisfy us that it will be along the same lines as the Department of Social Security, I will be interested to hear it because I think that there are other matters and problems involved than the ones that apply in the Department of Social Security.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement shows that a single pensioner was paying $20 in tax in the 1983-84 financial year. In this current financial year that amount will rise to $109. This will affect other pensioners in other categories commensurately.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the question of provisional tax which is included in this Bill. There is a reference to the increase in the rate at which incomes will be deemed to have risen for the purposes of provisional tax in this financial year. I see in the Minister's second reading speech that an increase of 10 per cent is expected in incomes this year. That comes as a bit of a surprise to me in the light of the Government's confident remarks that incomes will not be rising at anything like that rate in the current financial year. The Government is also confident that the inflation rate will be far lower than 10 per cent. I take it that because of the wonderful accord that exists between the union movement and the Government there are not likely to be wage increases over and above the indexation for inflation. I think that the Government claims an inflation figure this year of 4 or 5 per cent, so I wonder if the Minister will explain why the taxation office has included an extra 10 per cent in people's income for provisional tax purposes as against the likely inflation figure this year of 4 or 5 per cent. One must also bear in mind that the Government is confidently predicting to the Australian people that this level of increase will fall even further in future years. Why then has a figure of 10 per cent been selected? There could be one other possible explanation-that is that the Government has been telling us a pack of lies over the past year about the way in which labour costs will move in the next financial year.

I now turn to the Taxation Laws (Amendment) Bill and draw the Senate's attention to changes occurring in respect of penalties for companies. I particularly wish to draw attention to the new provisions for the reversal of the onus of proof on the part of managers and/or officers of companies where penalties are to apply. This provision is incorporated in section 8Y of the new Bill where it is deemed that the management, or any person taking part in the management of a corporation, shall be deemed to have committed the taxation offence for which the corporation is being punished, sued or prosecuted by virtue of the application of the penal clauses of the Act.

My point is that certainly one could make out a fair case for management being held responsible for the actions of the corporation and, indeed, there are examples of this under company law already. This is commonly referred to as 'the shedding of the company veil'. But I think a rather different interpretation should be put on this in the context of the taxation situation. On advice from the Taxation Commissioner, the Government is increasingly handing over discretions and/or making rights virtually absolute for the Commissioner to take action in certain cases and deeming situations to exist by virtue of particular interpretations of the law in an increasing number of circumstances that come before us for debate in this Parliament within new legislation. By virtue of this clause, there is another example of the move towards an absolute and categorical approach on the part of the Commissioner in order to ensure that certain circumstances are deemed to have occurred and then leaving it to the taxpayer to challenge that and take action in the courts to prove his innocence. Those unfortunate changes in the law and in the way it is administered are becoming all too common features of legislation these days.

In this case we have people who have been officers of companies, perhaps 10 or 15 years or even longer before a certain event has occurred which has led to the prosecution of a company, who can be taken up under this clause and deemed to have committed an offence. Those people then have to go into court and prove their innocence. That is contrary to all principles of British law and I believe that it is wrong in these circumstances. I draw attention to the particular section of the Bill which will create enormous problems for the future. It seems to follow the same kind of thinking that has been applied by this Government in seeking to retrospectively impose taxes upon people who have benefited from certain tax avoidance schemes. There is no need to develop that point any further, we have all debated legislation of that kind in this place at great length and I am sure that Senator Harradine for one would be aware of those circumstances. This kind of legislation appears to go down that same track. By reversing the onus of proof, by saying that people are guilty until they can prove themselves innocent, is something which I think needs to be brought to the attention of the people continually and exposed and debated in the community.

The second point that ought to be made is that obviously many former officers of companies engaged in the management of those companies over many years before their retirement will have done things which they may have forgotten the detail of but about which they have not had access to records of the company. All of these things will militate against them when they come to the courts to try to prove their innocence. We have to remember, too, that undoubtedly in a number of cases people who have retired and moved on into their old age will be forced to deal with circumstances which are far beyond them. No doubt they will be involved with heavy legal expense as well in trying to prove their innocence. All in all I think this is as the Law Council of Australia has said, a staggering and unprecedented reversal of the onus of proof, imposing an improper and necessary burden and a change in the fundamental rights of every Australian. I believe that the Government is wrong on this. Undoubtedly it will not change its mind because this legislation follows its approach, as I have pointed out. I anticipate that it will not consider this matter as being something for future amendment. I do hope that it administers this provision wisely and has guidelines in the future which are quite clear about what kind of people will be caught in these circumstances.

The other point that needs to be made about the reversal of the onus of proof provision is that one wonders whether fines or penalties imposed upon officers or former officers of companies, will create liabilities on the heirs and successors of those officers as a result of claiming under common law compensation for loss by the companies as a result of actions on the part of the officers of those companies, if that is deemed to be so rather than proven. I wonder whether the Government has considered that aspect and I would like to hear from it whether the Commissioner would be expected to take that into account. Of course one has to point out that it may not be the Commissioner who takes action in these cases; shareholders of a corporation itself may take action against officers where this kind of thing is proven.

I refer briefly to page 3 of the Minister's second reading speech, where he talks about a tax agent being convicted of the offence of knowingly making a false statement or failing to keep proper records, or of falsifying or concealing the identity of a person, et cetera. The penalty imposed upon the tax agent is that his or her registration will be suspended for a minimum of three months. As the Minister would know, most tax agents have blanket arrangements with the Taxation Commissioner for an extension of time for taxpayers to lodge their returns. If a tax agent's licence is suspended before taxpayers have lodged their returns under those arrangements, does it mean that those taxpayers would then be in default for not having lodged their returns, not being covered by those arrangements entered into by the tax agent, and therefore be subject to prosecution by the Taxation Commissioner? I would like to have the Government's assurance that innocent people in that situation will be protected against the Commissioner's actions.

On page 5 of the Minister's second reading speech there is reference to directors and company officers acting honestly and with reasonable competence in the management of a company's affairs not having anything to fear as a result of this legislation. I am glad to see the Minister's assurance in that respect. But I do want again to raise the question of unintentional errors, which do occur from time to time. What will be the Commissioner's guidelines in dealing with circumstances of that kind? I am really trying to establish whether directors and company officers who deem themselves to have made honest mistakes-apparently that is a term well known to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in particular, because he applies it to himself so often-are required to be overseen or judged by a court or whether the matter can be settled by negotiations in the normal way, with the Taxation Commissioner and the agent of the taxpayer or with whomsover might have an interest in the matter.

Mr Deputy President, I wish to draw one or two other minor points to your attention. Those points are in connection with the clauses relating to the new departure provisions. After reading page 9 of the second reading speech I am not entirely sure whether the service of a departure prohibition order on a person will be easily lifted in circumstances where that person can put down a clear case as to his liability. Will he have to await a full assessment by the Taxation Commissioner of his affairs? If so, if there are questions about past year losses or perhaps involvement in other transactions which are related to partnerships, trusts or other matters which require further checking and examination, will he be able to obtain readily the departure authorisation certificate which the Minister is going to institute in order to have people cleared for departure overseas? I can envisage all kinds of blockages arising in the system if there are not clear-cut guidelines and easy methods of administering this proposal, and I do hope that the Government has a clear understanding of the problems that it could be causing as a result.

I conclude merely by drawing attention to the remarks of the Government very early in this debate, and in particular to the remarks again of the Minister for Science and Technology who has demonstrated to us that this Government intends to raise taxes after the election if it is re-elected. It is only honest that the Government should say whether that is correct, and make its position clear. I do hope that in the course of its great rush of honesty to the head it will make clear its position on capital gains taxes, death duties and a harsher assets test before the election so that we can have a thorough debate on these matters in the course of the campaign that is to come upon us very soon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start my speech on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill by making a few general observations about taxation in this country, first of all with reference to the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Income Tax Assessment Act is the most voluminous Act we have in this country. The legislation which is before us today will add a staggering further 230 pages to that Act. Mr Deputy President, I am sure that you have seen a copy of that Act. It is almost the thickness of a telephone book for a major capital city. The average Australian simply cannot understand what is in it; nor, more importantly, can the average business man, either a big businessman on the board of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd or a small businessman running a backyard company with five or six people working for him.

SPEECH.PARA: That imposes very great limitations on business in Australia. We cannot have a situation in which we break our basic tenet that ignorance of the law is no defence. We simply cannot have people pleading ignorance and evading laws. There is an enormous argument for simplifying the Income Tax Assessment Act so that the majority of people involved in commerce at least understand most of what is involved in the Act. The two great needs in getting Australia back to economic health are, first of all, the reform of the Income Tax Assessment Act and, secondly, the reform of our industrial relations. Tragically, both those fields are getting worse and worse under a Labor government. Debate on this legislation is not the time for discussion on the industrial relations scene, but we have seen a marked consolidation and an expansion of the powers of the trade union movement; so much so that Mr Dolan spends more time in the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) than he spends in his own office as the head of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. We had the open and avowed involvement of the ACTU this year in planning the Budget. Perhaps that is one of the reasons why the deficit is so large.

We have to give business a break because it is only by the expansion of private industry in this country that we will get the unemployment figures down from where they are. A lot of nonsense has gone on about the new jobs which have been created in this country. I must point out that the overwhelming majority of those jobs that have been created under Labor have been created by expanding the Public Service, by spending other people's money to provide jobs in a non- competitive and largely non-productive environment. The rest of the growth in employment-that in private industry-regrettably has been low.

In reforming the tax system three broad goals have to be pursued: The Income Tax Assessment Act has to be simplified so that it will be more comprehensible to the average person; the Act itself has to be made a great deal fairer; and, above all, it has to provide an incentive for people to get out and earn some money. Both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have talked about reform in recent months but, as Senator Messner said, there are no details of this. They have a moral obligation-if they have any morals-to come clean with the Australian community and tell us the details of what they intend to do with their tax reform. I will come back to that a little later in my speech.

On the performance of the Government in the 18 months it has been in office we do not have any confidence that those reforms will be productive or rewarding for the Australian economy. We have seen very great taxation increases. The aggregate personal income tax take will go up by 23 per cent this year alone. The aggregate take from provisional tax will go up by a staggering 47 per cent. Of course, the individual rate for provisional tax has been hiked by 10 per cent in the face of a declared inflation rate of around 6.5 per cent, or whatever the Government is claiming. Every person who pays provisional tax is paying a 10 per cent increment this year. In this Budget we have seen the introduction of new tax scales. We now have five tax scales instead of three. That means, quite simply, that everyone pays more tax and pays it sooner.

In this chamber earlier in the week one of the Government senators made a very naive statement about the need to provide an incentive in the tax scheme. To his thinking, somehow or other the introduction of a new 25c in the dollar tax on a yearly income of $4,596 provided an incentive. I cannot understand that at all. It just means that someone who would not have paid income tax under the Liberal- National Party scales now has the dubious pleasure of paying tax to this Government. At the other end of the scale, people will now have the pleasure of paying the top rate of 60c in the dollar when their annual salary reaches $35, 001, instead of when it reaches $35,789. It is absolutely wrong for any person to be paying more tax to the Government than that person is able to make out of his activities. We simply cannot have an incentive when the major part of the reward for that effort is going to an impersonal government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General will recall explaining to the Senate in answer to a question of mine on Wednesday the forms of investigation which could be launched by the National Crime Authority and saying that what was happening at the moment essentially was 'sifting and processing', to use his own words, the Costigan information. I ask whether the Attorney-General is aware that on the same day the Special Minister of State, referring to Mr Costigan, told the House of Representatives:

QUESTION.PARA: All the investigations he has handed over to the National Crime Authority are still being carried out.

Does the Attorney agree that like the Prime Minister, who mistakenly referred to references having been given to the Authority from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the Special Minister of State has also sought to mislead the public by suggesting that the Authority is currently engaged in full scale pursuit of criminals identified by Mr Costigan? Why does the Government persist with trying to create this impression when on the Attorney's own admission the Authority is involved in little more than an assessment of the Costigan material?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Opposition is going to derive nourishment from these semantic trivialities, I will do my best to accommodate it. There is no substantial point here involved. The Costigan investigations are still being pursued to the extent that there is collation, there is analysis, as I understand it, going on in relation to the Costigan material and collators and data input people are continuing to operate. Investigations are being pursued in the sense that none of them are not being pursued and no decision has been made to terminate any particular investigation. Obviously, that is so because we are in the middle, clearly, of a transition process, which process is not complete either in the sense of initiating new formal references which will enable the exercise of coercive powers or in the sense of decisions being made not to pursue particular lines of inquiry that have been initiated by the Costigan Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: I ought to say that a number of the Costigan investigations that are now summarised in the now famous 42 summaries document were investigations which have not in fact been taken very far by the Costigan Commission or in which nothing much in many instances had been done for a very long time. A lot of them were simply recording information which had been received and which might or might not need to be followed up as a result of further investigative effort at some later stage. But all these considerations are consistent both with what I have told the Senate and with what Mr Young, the Special Minister of State, has told the House, and I see no justification at all for the attempt to drive some sort of opportunistic wedge between different ways of expressing the same state of affairs that the honourable senator is now attempting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In computing the income of a service pensioner for the purposes of the income test, are disability pensions disregarded as income? In the same way, are disability pensions disregarded in calculating the rate of supplementary assistance payable to a service pensioner? If not, what would be the cost of introducing this concession to those who would otherwise be eligible to receive supplementary assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked quite a number of questions in the last year or so about the pensions paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I think it has to be said that there is a degree of confusion about them. There are two substantial types of pensions. One is a social welfare pension, known as the service pension, and the other group of pensions can be described largely as compensatory, covering disability pensions, including totally and permanently incapacitated pensions, the attendant's allowance, recreation and transport allowance, war widow's pensions, et cetera. A great deal of confusion has crept into that area when issues such as the assets test, tax and other matters have been debated in the Parliament in recent months. I stress that the disability pension is completely disregarded as income in the assessment of a service pension entitlement. In addition it is paid tax free. It is free of any income test and will not be subject to the forthcoming assets test. This is in recognition of the compensatory nature of the disability pension.

ANSWER.PARA: The disability pension is, however, treated as income in determining a service pensioner's eligibility for supplementary assistance for rent allowance, a matter that was stressed by Senator Colston in his question. This is because the supplementary assistance is paid strictly on the basis of need to those pensioners who are identified as being in dire circumstances and therefore meet the guidelines; in particular it is paid to those whose weekly rents represent a large portion of their total financial resources. The current maximum supplementary assistance is $10 a week and as a result of the recent Budget that is to rise in November to $15 a week. About 26,000 service pensioners receive such supplementary assistance. If the disability pension were to be disregarded in determining service pensions entitlement in supplementary assistance, about 5 ,000 service pensioners would become eligible for supplementary assistance. So the annual cost of such a measure would be about $2m at current rates or about $ 3m at the new rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of Mr Justice McClelland, a former senator and Minister. I welcome him back to the Senate.

—I remind the Attorney-General of answers that he gave to Senate Estimates Committee E last Tuesday evening in relation to the National Crime Authority's vote. The result of his answers was that he said that at the moment apart from the commissioners there are four lawyers engaged on a full time or part time basis on the sifting of the Costigan material. I ask whether the Attorney is aware of a statement made last night by his colleague the Special Minister of State in which that Minister referred to another 20 people who were working on this same material, additional to the lawyers mentioned by Senator Evans on Tuesday. I ask: Did those extra 20 people take up their full time positions within the last 48 hours and what are the qualifications and functions of the staff who were described by Mr Young as analysts and of the six who were described as collators. What are their qualifications and what is their status?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the last part of that question relating to the qualifications and status of the persons described as collators and analysts, I will have to take that on notice, and seek a reply. As to the first part of the question, the reality is that this week we are in the middle of a formal transition of staff from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to the Crime Authority. It is the case , I am told, that 89 of the Costigan staff formally transferred to the NCA as of 1 October, that is to say, the beginning of this week, but on the basis that the Commissioner would continue to have priority on their services for his report. I am told that 80 per cent of these people have in turn, as of this week, largely completed their work on the report and the NCA is paying their salaries now. Arrangements are being put in place this week for them to do work under the direction of the Authority.

ANSWER.PARA: It was of course the case that a significant proportion of the Costigan staff was continuing to spend time, as I indicated in answer a moment ago to Senator MacGibbon, on the collation and analysis on a continuing basis of material that was already in the possession of the Costigan Commission and was, of course, also the subject of the Costigan summaries transferred to the NCA.

Once again one can argue about which particular box these people are to be described as being in at any given point in time, but it is an unproductive argument because we are in the middle of a transition process in which the Authority is mobilising resources. It is not recreating resources externally. It would be a pointless, futile, expensive waste of time to create a separate bureaucracy when the full transfer of the Costigan staff resources is so imminent. Once again I believe there is no inconsistency in anything I may have told the Senate Estimates Committee as to the work of lawyers working specifically on advising the Authority as to what might properly be the subject of a formal reference and what Mr Young might have said last night so far as the overall staffing position is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I understand from that answer that the extra people mentioned by the Special Minister of State have only just been transferred? Are they part of this group that was transferred to the Authority only the other day?

—The three members have only just been transferred to the formal authority of the National Crime Authority, but that is not to say that they have only just started work on the particular Costigan material because the job that a great many of these people have been doing all along has been working on the further adding to and refinement of and reshaping of the material that has been in the Costigan Commission's possession. I am not in a position to give any more detail on that. I will see what further information the Special Minister of State is able to supply.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. What is the progress of the Government's steel industry plan? In particular, has Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd continued to make the investments it pledged as part of its contribution to the plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed opportune that Senator Richardson should choose today to ask that particular question. I am able to inform the Senate that the progress of the steel industry plan is very satisfactory to the Government and marks a reversal in the fortunes of the steel industry. I just remind the Senate that when this Government came to office the steel industry was in disarray and grave fears were held for the future of that industry. The Government acted quickly to put into operation the steel industry plan which provided--
—Huh!
—Senator Boswell finds that amusing. I repeat that the Government acted quickly, something Senator Boswell has not done in his time here that I have noticed.
—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I made absolutely no remark. I was sitting here quite innocently and was attacked by the Leader of the Opposition.
—There is no point of order.

—I was making the point that the Government acted quickly to put in place a steel industry plan which provided job security for workers in the industry as well as assistance from the Government in exchange for a commitment by the company to invest and modernise its steel plant.

ANSWER.PARA: I am very pleased to be able to inform the Senate that today BHP announced its decision to install a second continuous slab caster at the Port Kembla steelworks. This is a major investment involving some $146m and will mean virtually that all the Port Kembla steel will be continuous cast by 1988. That is front line technology in the steel industry and the Government very much welcomes this announcement by BHP. Other evidence is, of course, relevant to Senator Richardson's question. I refer to the fact that annual production is now running at some six million tonnes a year, close to operating capacity. Production in the period January to August 1984 increased by 15 per cent over the same period last year. Profit for the steel industry division in 1984 was $72m, representing a 3 per cent return on funds. As I said, the Government welcomes this progress in the steel industry and looks forward to presiding over further improvement in that industry in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I assure him that I do not wish to drive an opportunistic wedge between him and his fellow Ministers by asking this question, but I would like to get some acknowledgment of real concern on his part and evidence of real determination to deal with crime in an effective way. So I ask the Attorney: Does he share the widespread concern at the continuing series of allegations affecting the administration of justice and law enforcement in the State of New South Wales? Does he agree that matters such as the prisoner early release scandal, the Humphreys-Farquhar case, the Cessna-Milner case, last weekend's allegations about large scale police involvement in the heroin trade, and all the matters made public in the Age tapes and the transcripts are part of what seems to be an evergrowing mosaic of crime and corruption in that State? Given the Commonwealth's direct interest in the proper operation of that State's judicial system and the fact that close co- operation is required between law enforcement agencies of both Governments, I ask: Has the Attorney had any discussions with the Prime Minister or any other relevant Federal ministerial colleagues as to what action might be taken by the Commonwealth to allay evergrowing public concern at this apparently uncheckable explosion of illegal activity? If he has, has any action been proposed? If he has not, will he initiate such discussions and suggest that Federal and State Ministers should meet in the near future to consider in what way this worrying trend might be reversed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the only evident trend in this matter is in the rhetoric of the Opposition which has been escalating with great rapidity as we come closer to the election date. I notice that the problem of organised crime is not so intensely felt by the Leader of the Opposition that he even bothered to contribute to the debate on the National Crime Authority when that particular parliamentary occasion presented itself in the House of Representatives a few months ago. Of course it is the case that any series of allegations about organised crime is a matter of concern for any government anywhere in this country. To the extent that allegations are continuing to be made about crime in New South Wales it is obviously a matter of concern for the New South Wales Government as it is for everyone else in this country. Equally, it is the case that the New South Wales Government is acting with considerable expedition, dispatch and competence in dealing with these allegations as they are made, one at a time. I will not be party here or anywhere else to the kind of state of mind which has been so assiduously cultivated by the Opposition in recent days, weeks and months, namely, that the mere making of an allegation or innuendo is itself sufficient evidence that there is justification for that allegation being made. It is a matter of waiting for the processes of the court system to work themselves out before making strident and over-confident assertions of the kind we hear so often from the other side. Those processes are working themselves out .

ANSWER.PARA: So far as the Commonwealth's role in all this is concerned, we have, of course, been anxious to set in place and to maintain co-operative law enforcement arrangements with all the States, not just New South Wales. As I indicated in answer to a question a few days ago, joint taskforces have been very productive indeed in dealing in recent years with the particular problem of drug trafficking. The whole question of Federal-State co-operation in dealing with organised crime has been what the whole debate on the Crime Authority has been about over the last 18 months and indeed going back into the life of the previous Government. The big difference between our approach to this matter and that of the previous Government is that we have succeeded in putting into place through the agency of the Crime Authority co-operative arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States which will genuinely ensure that a major attack is mounted on these phenomena. There is nothing whatsoever to apologise about so far as this Government's approach to organised crime and the fighting of it is concerned. Our budgetary allocations for that purpose, through the Australian Federal Police, the doubling of expenditure on the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and the further additions to the expenditure that will be incurred this year, bringing expenditure for the Crime Authority up to $8.6m, all attest to that state of affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question which follows the suggestion in the early part of the reply from the Attorney-General that the concern being expressed by the Opposition was related to the nearness of an election. TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Territories and Local Government to figures on the allocation of funds by the Queensland Government to the various local government authorities in that State through the Queensland Grants Commission. Is the Minister aware that the percentage increases for 1984-85 in allocations to these authorities vary dramatically between the different regions of the State? In particular, does the Minister agree that the western shires of Queensland have been savagely discriminated against by the Queensland Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the figures arising out of the decision of the Queensland Grants Commission which has the responsibility of allocating Federal funds to the various local government authorities in Queensland. One can only come to the conclusion that it has done so on a highly discriminatory basis. The purpose of the Grants Commission is, of course, to top up or even up the facilities and resources in local government areas. But that practice is not being followed in respect of Queensland. —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to reports in the Australian Financial Review, indicating that the consumer electronics industry, in a submission to the Economic Planning Advisory Council, has called for the adoption of a retail consumption tax as a substitute for sales tax?
